content.title: Native, unrivalled locavore cocktails

introduction.small: In the heart of the Telok Ayer neighbourhood, very popular with food lovers, the Native bar prepares surprising cocktails from unusual regional ingredients.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Native, unrivalled locavore cocktails

paragraphs.text:
Far from a globalised world, Native promotes local skills and products. In this cocktail bar located on restaurant-heavy Amoy Street, locavorism is key: rum is from Thailand, gin from Singapore, cinnamon from Sri Lanka… Like a true explorer, Vijay Mudaliar roams his region looking for new flavours, distils all kinds of ingredients and tries new recipes for his drinks.
The mixologist gives pride of place to his Singaporean roots and to the South Asian spirit, in his cocktails and in the decoration (that showcases frescoes by street artist Rajesh Kumar). The Pineapple Arrack is thus made of Ceylon Arrack, a Sri Lankan spirit, various forms of coconut (water, oil and shell), spices and a cinnamon-covered pineapple slice on top. Even more eccentric, the house signature drink, Antz, is based on sugar cane, coco yogurt, Jasmin flowers and… ants. Guaranteed originality!

Native
52A Amoy Street
Singapore

+65 8869 6520

www.tribenative.com

Menu: cocktails from 20 SGD

content.title: The Parkroyal on Pickering, a ‘green' garden hotel

introduction.small: An ecological hotel with abundant parks—a little bit of zen in the heart of bustling Singapore.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Parkroyal on Pickering, a ‘green' garden hotel

paragraphs.text:
Sustainable development is a philosophy for Parkroyal on Pickering, designed by Woha Architects. Reclaimed rainwater, solar energy production, and use of wood materials openly display this value, as do the futuristic lines made timeless by the contemporary zen aspect of its interior design.

Some 367 rooms and suites with views of Chinatown and Hong Lim Park bring you peace and serenity, while walkways provide direct access to the gardens. A relaxation area is at your disposal, where you will find a spa and a gym. On the top floor, take a dip in the infinity pool and treat yourself to a breath-taking view of the city in a green paradise, home to fifty different plant varieties.

Parkroyal on Pickering
3 Upper Pickering Street
058289 Singapore

+65 6809 8888

www.parkroyalhotels.com/en/hotels-resorts/singapore/pickering

Rooms: from 217 EUR

content.title: Finish your meal in Singapore at “2am: dessertbar"

introduction.small: A dessert bar for those who love sweets, even late at night.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Finish your meal in Singapore at “2am: dessertbar"

paragraphs.text:
A little pause at “2am” is needed to recharge your batteries before continuing your evening. As its name suggests, this place welcomes you until late at night, perfect for those who have a tremendous desire for sweetness or a little night-time craving. This dessert paradise is in the Holland Village neighbourhood where chef Janice Wong offers a multitude of culinary creations, as original and colourful as they are appetizing. In a minimalist decor, subdued lighting, white walls, sleek furniture and soft music invite you to take a seat for a moment of sweetness.

On the menu, each dessert is associated with a cocktail. This simple suggestion may well bring you some nice surprises. Try, for example, Cacao Forest—chocolate mousse with mixed berries, topped with crème de cacao liqueur, miso vanilla whisky ice cream and vanilla custard, while drinking a few sips of a cocktail of whiskey, crème de cacao, green tea and Cilla Pedro Ximénez sherry.

2am : dessertbar
21a Lorong Liput
Holland Village
Singapore

+65 6291 9727

www.2amdessertbar.com

Dessert: from 24 SGD

content.title: The Singapore Flyer: a giant Ferris wheel with a 360° view

introduction.small: Towering 165 metres high, the Singapore Flyer offers a breath-taking panorama of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Singapore Flyer: a giant Ferris wheel with a 360° view

paragraphs.text:
Inaugurated in 2008, the Singapore Flyer is one of the world's tallest Ferris wheels. During a dizzying ride of about 30 minutes, you can see all of the city's main attractions the Singapore River, Raffles, Merlion Park, and Marina Bay Sands.

It's the perfect opportunity to snap photos, from up above one end of the marina. The experience is nothing like that of the Ferris wheel rides of yore. The cabins are spacious and fully closed. You can book for dinner, for an unforgettable evening in an atypical setting. The Moët & Chandon cabin plays background music and serves Champagne. Choose whatever hour you wish: early in the morning, at sunset, or late at night.

Singapore Flyer
30 Raffles Ave
Singapore

+65 6333 3311

www.singaporeflyer.com

content.title: Lau Pa Sat Market: a concentration of culinary traditions

introduction.small: This pavilion nestled in the heart of the financial district offers an authentic dining experience.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lau Pa Sat Market: a concentration of culinary traditions

paragraphs.text:
There is a special atmosphere here that bubbles with energy and tradition. Also known as the ‘Telor Ayer Market', the Lau Pa Sat market (literally ‘Old Market'), founded in the 19th century, recently renovated, and a national monument since 1973, is a masterpiece of colonial architecture. The octagonal Victorian metal structure houses a traditional atmosphere, where fragrances and flavours blend to make it the epitome of Singaporean culture. One of the few historic buildings in the heart of the financial district of the city, it is a rallying point for tourists and locals.

Try culinary specialties like satay chicken or beef skewers with peanut sauce, or a slightly spicy crab chilli. Lau Pa Sat also has an impressive variety of fresh fish and seafood. The Chinese dim sum dishes are superb, as are the Indian naan.

Free concerts are held at night and on weekends.

Lau Pa Sat Market
18 Raffles Quay
Singapore

+65 6220 2138

content.title: Hai Tien Lo: the temple of Chinese cuisine

introduction.small: Beautiful views, ancient recipes, and perfect service in one of the best Chinese restaurants on the island.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hai Tien Lo: the temple of Chinese cuisine

paragraphs.text:
In a sober and refined setting sprinkled with elegant Asian touches, this restaurant on the top floor of the Pan Pacific Hotel offers 360° views. It highlights the sweet flavours of Cantonese cuisine, meticulously presented with a modern twist. Enjoy roast pork barbecue, a house specialty, succumb to the steaming baskets of delicious dim sum, or let yourself be tempted by the wide variety of traditional and contemporary recipes.

The menu offers many meats and vegetables prepared in a century-old tradition. A fragrant tea complements your meal. Light and purifying, the drink will leave you with a note of sweetness that perfectly matches the Cantonese cuisine.

Hai Tien Lo
Pan Pacific Hotel
7 Raffles Boulevard
Singapore

+65 6826 8240

www.panpacific.com/en/hotels-resorts/singapore/marina/stay/dining/hai-tien-lo.html

Menu: from 70 SGD

content.title: The best-kept secret in Singapore

introduction.small: Far from the bustling, frenetic metropolis, these beautiful islands provide exceptional moments of relaxation.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The best-kept secret in Singapore

paragraphs.text:
The artificial island of Sentosa is the best known, but it's also the most developed and tourist-oriented of the islands of Singapore.

If you want to truly get away, head out to the somewhat more distant islands, where there are fewer tourists and the more tranquil atmosphere still has the charm of yesteryear. Several options are available, depending on your interests. Pulau Ubi is quiet, beautiful, and deserted. Prized for its rich fauna, flora, beaches, and quarries, there you can still find some of the rural character of Singapore, and authentic cuisine based on fresh fish and seafood.

Kusu Island, literally ‘Turtle Island', is a sanctuary that attracts locals in search of good fortune and tourists on a mystical pilgrimage to its many temples and statues. To fully enjoy the sea, go to St John's Island, with its beautiful lagoons, where calm and serenity reign supreme. A lucky few might spot pink dolphins off the coast, while others can go diving in the magical and colourful world of underwater corals.

Singapore Island Cruise
01-04 Marina South Pier
Singapore

+65 6534 9339

www.islandcruise.com.sg

content.title: Colony Ritz Carlton: an innovative and gourmet approach to the buffet

introduction.small: An explosion of Asian and Western flavours in a refined and tasty buffet.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Colony Ritz Carlton: an innovative and gourmet approach to the buffet

paragraphs.text:
In the elegant colonial atmosphere of the Ritz Carlton, the Colony provides a true gastronomic adventure at any time of the day.

You can watch the chefs prepare your food carefully in one of eight cooking stations open to the restaurant in the centre. Among the delicacies on offer: sashimi, smoked Iberian pork with Balinese spices, famous laksa noodle soup in a coconut milk broth, here flavoured with lobster. Many different kinds of freshly squeezed juices are available, and you can watch the chef make noodles right before your eyes.

To end your week on a sparkling note, the restaurant offers a Sunday ‘vintage brunch' where the delicious dishes are accompanied by Champagne.

Colony Ritz Carlton
7 Raffles Avenue
Singapore

+65 6434 5288

www.ritzcarlton.com/en/Properties/Singapore/Dining/Colony/

Menu: from 78 SGD

content.title: Raffles Hotel: luxury icon

introduction.small: More than 130 years after opening, Raffles Hotel lives up to its reputation—and more! Take a trip into the past.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Raffles Hotel: luxury icon

paragraphs.text:
Join the ranks of the many personalities who have stayed at Raffles, this enchanting jewel of old. The hotel opened its doors in 1887, before going through complete renovations worthy of its magnificent past.

Impeccable and attentive service, and charming colonial rooms combine to create a place that will relax you body and mind. The infinity pool on the roof has a panoramic view of the city, especially dramatic at sunset. The shopping arcade, which is lined with famous designer shops, will delight shopaholics.

Anyone who is passionate about the past will be pleased to encounter the hotel's historian, who will tell you all the secrets of this emblematic place. The artistically landscaped gardens, stylish and quiet in the heart of the capital, will bring a finishing touch to your dream holiday.

Raffles Hotel
1 Beach Road
Singapore

+65 6337 1886

www.raffles.com/singapore/

Rooms: from 623 SGD

content.title: The 21st century gardens of the Gardens by the Bay

introduction.small: Behind the impressive magnificence of the Marina Bay Sands hotel hides a green jewel of modernity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The 21st century gardens of the Gardens by the Bay

paragraphs.text:
This huge park, recently opened, takes you into a futuristic atmosphere with breath-taking views of a megalopolis whose reputation as a garden city seems fully justified. Go for a walk and breathe in fresh air while admiring the Marina Bay Sands and the urban landscape.

In a calm atmosphere, Singapore offers here an invitation to enjoy nature. Two giant biomes stand at one end of the park, designed as biodiversity conservation areas, with a strong pedagogical component. Observe the different plant and flower species from Mediterranean and subtropical climactic zones in the Flower Dome.

Admire the highest indoor waterfall in the world (nearly 35 metres high) inside the Cloud Forest. Then immerse yourself in the heights of the Skywalk where, surrounded by metal structures covered with greenery that give life to these giant artificial trees, you'll be rewarded with a spectacular view of the city.

Gardens by the Bay
18 Marina Gardens Dr
Singapore

+65 6420 6848

www.gardensbythebay.com.sg/en.html

content.title: Cé La Vi: the best of Singapore in one place

introduction.small: A modern and refined Asian cuisine, cradled in a glamorous atmosphere, with a breath-taking view of the marina.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cé La Vi: the best of Singapore in one place

paragraphs.text:
Formerly Ku De Ta, this popular spot perfectly combines the best that Singapore has to offer: a panoramic view, exquisite Asian cuisine, and a chic ambience. Located above the observation deck of the famous Marina Bay Sands resort, this bar-restaurant has a terrace and an indoor room with large windows.

The Asian decor is elegant and modern. The menu offers a variety of Asian dishes, from sushi to seafood, exotic salads, and gourmet rice. Each specialty is conceived as a work of art. Presented as several dishes to share, a meal here is very convivial. The cocktails are creatively made by high-flying professionals. The service is attentive: the staff goes out of its way to make dining here an exceptional experience.

Cé La Vi
1 Bayfront Avenue
Singapore

+65 6508 2188

www.sg.celavi.com/

Menu: from 168 SGD

content.title: Jurong Bird Park: an educational family getaway

introduction.small: The park provides the opportunity for an exceptional encounter with over 5,000 birds of 400 different species.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Jurong Bird Park: an educational family getaway

paragraphs.text:
The Jurong Bird Park is the largest bird sanctuary in the region, with colourful species from around the world: giant African Turaco, all in blue, up in the trees, black Tasmanian swans in the water, penguins from Antarctica on the shore.

The incredible diversity makes for a rich educational experience for kids and a paradise for birdwatchers. Take part in one of the many activities offered by the park. Stop for a few minutes amid the cacophony to feed the parrots or admire the majestically soaring eagles overhead. If you can extend your visit until the end of the day, why not dine with the penguins? It a marvellous stroll, fun for the whole family.

Jurong Bird Park
2 Jurong Hill
Singapore

+65 6269 3411

www.birdpark.com.sg

content.title: Trishaw tour: discover Singapore aboard a traditional vehicle

introduction.small: An experience combining cultural tradition, discovery, and anecdotes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Trishaw tour: discover Singapore aboard a traditional vehicle

paragraphs.text:
A comfortable ride aboard one of these traditional taxis will take you into the very heart of everyday Singaporean life.

Before the modernisation of Singapore, trishaws (three-wheeled vehicles with pedals) were the most common means of transport, and it is still common to see them roaming the streets in some Asian countries. Find your driver-guide at Albert Mall Trishaw Park, take a seat, and get ready for some 30 minutes of discovery. Aboard the trishaw, you'll travel into the heart of the most effervescent neighbourhoods of Singapore Bugis and Little India. Your guide will regale you with historical anecdotes. Flower merchants, fortune-tellers, markets full of colourful fruits and vegetables you are fully immersed in local life.

Choose the option that includes the Singapore River if you want a bit of fresh air, and check out the impressive buildings lining the waterway.

Trishaw Uncle
1 North Bridge Road
15-06, High Street Centre
Singapore

+65 6337 7111

www.trishawuncle.com.sg

content.title: Raffles Long Bar: the origin of the Singapore Sling

introduction.small: What better way to enjoy the famous Singaporean cocktail than in the very place where it was created?

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Raffles Long Bar: the origin of the Singapore Sling

paragraphs.text:
The decor is reminiscent of an upscale English pub. The star here is the famous Singapore Sling, which was concocted for the first time in 1915 by Ngiam Tong Boon.

The ingredients of this delicious cocktail are good gin, cherry brandy, pineapple juice, Benedictine, Cointreau, a dash of grenadine, and a slice of lime. The bar offers different versions and non-alcoholic preparations.

Another bonus here: this is one of the few places in Singapore where it is legal to dirty the floor! Feel free to toss your peanut shells, as is the custom. At the heart of this historical setting, you will find no better place to savour the local cocktail.

Raffles Long Bar
1 Beach Road
Singapore

+65 6412 1816

www.raffles.com/singapore/dining/long-bar/

Drinks: from 30 SGD

content.title: The Quincy Hotel: a perfect stay in the heart of the city

introduction.small: Centrally located, the Quincy has all the components needed to create a perfect stay.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Quincy Hotel: a perfect stay in the heart of the city

paragraphs.text:
Only minutes walk from the popular Orchard Road and the orchid garden, this hotel of charming contemporary design is nestled in the hills of Mount Elizabeth.

The rooms are small but have large windows that provide stunning views of the Singapore skyline. The bedding is of exceptional quality. Located slightly away from the city's busiest arteries, it is a true cocoon where tranquillity reigns. Stop at the 12th floor and dive into the infinity glass pool that overlooks the city.

The service is friendly and the hotel offers all-inclusive package deals, something that is not common in Singapore. From breakfast on, the feast for the eyes begins, as you look out of the large window onto a beautifully landscaped garden…

Quincy Hotel
22 Mount Elizabeth
Singapore

+65 6738 5888

www.quincy.com.sg

Rooms: from 184 SGD

content.title: Sri Mariamman Temple: the oldest Hindu temple in the country

introduction.small: Beautifully decorated in the Dravidian art tradition, this place of worship, open to all, is an oasis of colour.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sri Mariamman Temple: the oldest Hindu temple in the country

paragraphs.text:
Dedicated to the goddess Mariamman, who holds the power of healing, this temple was established in 1827 and has been renovated several times since. Before entering, observe in detail the impressive gopuram, the multi-coloured tower. The sculptures of Hindu deities contain sacred meanings and were carved with care by the best artists in the country. Joining them is Krishna, the god behind all the others, recognisable by his blue body and the flute he holds in his fingers.

Remove your shoes, step into the captivating atmosphere, and make a tour moving from left to right. Let yourself be carried away by the sound of pealing bells, rung by devotees to attract luck. Before sunset, priests, worshipers, and musicians begin the ritual offerings.

The Timiti celebration is held from October to November, during which the most courageous believers walk barefoot over burning coals.

Sri Mariamman Temple
244 South Bridge Road
Singapore

+65 6223 4064

www.mt.org.sq

content.title: Hotel 1929: intimate comfort five minutes from Chinatown

introduction.small: Nestled in a renovated colonial trade building, the Hotel 1929 offers uniquely charming decor.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel 1929: intimate comfort five minutes from Chinatown

paragraphs.text:
A fusion between chic and retro decor in the heart of one of the liveliest areas of the city, Hotel 1929 is perfect for couples or single travellers. The halls are lined with vintage black-and-white photos of Singapore. Rooms are intimate, cosy and quiet. Located on the vibrant Keong Saik Road, the neighbourhood is noisy but only a few steps separate you from the stalls in Chinatown or the Outram MRT station, from where you can easily get to the shopping mecca of Orchard Road. Soak up the sun on the lovely wooden patio, and then dine at Bistro November, which serves delicious European cuisine with Asian accents, all in a minimalist decor.

Hotel 1929
50 Keong Saik Road
Singapore

+65 6347 1929

www.hotel1929.com

Rooms: from 119 SGD

content.title: An idyllic stay at the Fullerton Hotel Singapore

introduction.small: The Fullerton Hotel Singapore, a magnificent legacy, is world-renowned.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: An idyllic stay at the Fullerton Hotel Singapore

paragraphs.text:
You can't miss the monumental architecture of the Fullerton, located on the main Singapore River pier in the marina, where an underpass leads you to the property. The city's symbol since its construction in 1928, it has long been the centre of social and economic activity in the city-state.

Today, it is just as much an icon as it is a luxurious hotel. Ask for a room overlooking the river. The rooms are decorated in elegant colonial style, and the luxury can be felt in every detail. The attentive and friendly service will make your stay perfect.

Come to the edge of the majestic 25-metre pool for a swim, while admiring the unique view of the marina. Then treat yourself to a tasty snack at the chocolate buffet at teatime, and finish your day with a drink at the hotel's rooftop bar.

Fullerton Hotel Singapore
1 Fullerton Square
Singapore

+65 6733 8388

www.fullertonhotel.com

Rooms: from 348 SGD

content.title: National Gallery: art treasures at the crossroads of history and modernity

introduction.small: A fascinating tour of modern art in Singapore and Southeast Asia, through the innovative use of technology.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: National Gallery: art treasures at the crossroads of history and modernity

paragraphs.text:
The architectural icons of the former Supreme Court and City Hall have been turned into this true jewel of modern art. The largest art museum in Southeast Asia opened in November 2015 and has more than 800 works on permanent display.

Discover the history of a country and a region from the perspective of artistic movements that have evolved in parallel to social movements since the 19th century. The museum represents perfectly the contrast between cultural history and modernity. You can download the museum's app on your phone an innovative way to visit a gallery that allows you to plan your personalised visit in advance, participate in discussion forums on the works, and listen to the fascinating history of the paintings.

For children, the Keppel Centre for Art Education will stimulate their creativity in a true artist's studio. They can play with light and colour in a work of interactive art and develop their curiosity in an enchanted forest.

National Gallery Singapore
1 St. Andrew's Road
Singapore

+65 6271 7000

www.nationalgallery.sg

content.title: See Singapore on scooter

introduction.small: Jump on your scooter and discover Singapore from an entirely new angle.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: See Singapore on scooter

paragraphs.text:
Forget the traditional bus or walking tour and see the monuments of the city unfold before your eyes from the saddle of your new horse. This guided tour, which lasts about four hours, presents the historical evolution of Singapore from colonial town to modern city.

The starting point is the Cenotaph, the First World War memorial in the Esplanade Park. You then cross the Padang (Malay for ‘field') and let the fresh air caress your face down at the docks that line the Singapore River. After admiring the impressive structures of Merlion Park, you ride slowly towards the modernity of the impressive Marina Bay Sands.

Your route will take you into the tranquillity of the botanic gardens, before returning you to the Esplanade. A somewhat sporty visit but adapted to everyone and an original way to discover the city.

City by the Water Kick Scooter Tour
200 JooChiat Road
Singapore

+65 6247 7340

www.betelboxtours.com

content.title: The Merlion: symbol of Singapore

introduction.small: On the resplendent Marina Bay is the impressive Merlion, a statue of a lion's head with the body of a fish that has become the legend of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Merlion: symbol of Singapore

paragraphs.text:
The Merlion is the personification of Singaporean values. One of the few monuments in this ultra-modern city, it honours its history. Singapura literally means ‘the city of the lion', and the statue traces the evolution of what was once a fishing village named Temasek.

Yet the use of the Merlion as a symbol of the city-state is fairly recent, as it was only adopted by the tourist office in 1964. The Marina Bay statue was created that same year by the Englishman Alec Fraser-Brunner. In 2002 it was relocated to its current place. It is 8.6 metres in height and a jet of water gushes from its mouth into the Singapore River.

It provides a memorable image of the city, especially at night, when it is dramatically lit.

Merlion Park
Singapore

content.title: Haji Lane: home to Singapore's trendiest shops and bars

introduction.small: The polar opposite of the shopping malls of Orchard Road, this dynamic little street, tucked away in the district of Kampong Glam, teems with hip treasures.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Haji Lane: home to Singapore's trendiest shops and bars

paragraphs.text:
Haji Lane does not fit into the image most people have of Singapore. Here, there are no gleaming shopping malls or international brands. On this street in the heart of Kampong Glam, close to the Sultan Mosque and Arab Street and once inhabited by the lower classes, many independent shops have emerged. The renovation of the street's small, narrow houses has attracted a new population. The ambience is picturesque and ultra-colourful, with many hipster cafés and restaurants, and tucked-away shops. Stroll through the atmospheric streets in the evening. Check out the original creations of the Know Nothing store before dining in the Pluck, a trendy restaurant-bar serving affordable and delicious fusion food an incredible mix of harmonious culinary styles.

There is no shortage of other cool, one-of-a-kind boutiques, including Salad Shop, which sells decorative objects in a minimalist decor of black and white.

Haji Lane
Singapore

content.title: Singapore Botanic Gardens: a green jewel in the city's heart

introduction.small: The only tropical garden that is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, this is a breath of fresh air, just beyond the city centre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Singapore Botanic Gardens: a green jewel in the city's heart

paragraphs.text:
This 158-year-old tropical forest is a must. Early birds will appreciate it as the sunrise's first rays of light hit the marina. The tropical garden in the heart of the park is home to over 10,000 different species of flowers and stretches over 82 hectares. After a refreshing break at the lakes, lose yourself in the gardens of bamboo and bonsai. Proceed through the Sun Garden, where you will see cactus, yuccas, and other plants from arid climates. The highlight of the walk is the famous orchid garden. The collection of some 1,000 species is alone worth the visit. The children's garden is also a delight. The atmosphere is very peaceful, and the plethora of colours is spectacular.

Singapore Botanic Gardens
1 Cluny Road
Singapore

+65 6471 7138

www.sbg.org.sg

content.title: The Singapore Zoo Night Safari: a unique exploration

introduction.small: At the world's first night zoo, discover the lives of the most feared animals in Southeast Asia.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Singapore Zoo Night Safari: a unique exploration

paragraphs.text:
Darkness falls on this rainforest, and dampness infuses the air. Save the little train ride for later start instead with the walking tour, during which you'll meet 130 species of animals.

Dive into the heart of the Australian jungles on the new Wallaby Trail where, after frightening encounters with night predators like the white-lipped python, you can relax again, surrounded by playful kangaroos and possums. Open your eyes very wide and you might catch a glimpse of some grey frogmouths, night birds that are the kings of camouflage. Then start off on the Fishing Cat Trail, where you can watch the fishing cat perform the art of night fishing to perfection.

You'll have never walked so close to the largest and most fearsome jungle feline than you will on the Leopard Trail and the East Lodge Trail: Malaysian tigers, Sri Lankan leopards and the famous king of the jungle, the Gir Lion. A journey into the animal world in the heart of the city, this is a completely unique nocturnal expedition.

Singapore Zoo Night Safari
80 Mandai Lake Road
Singapore

+65 6269 3411

www.nightsafari.com.sg

content.title: Universal Studios: an adventure odyssey

introduction.small: At the heart of Resorts World Sentosa, an island of attractions and temptations, stands a theme park that is unique in Asia.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Universal Studios: an adventure odyssey

paragraphs.text:
Universal Studios Singapore is a unique place in the region, and it provides an unparalleled cinematic experience in an impressive setting.

Travel through time and space by means of a splendid array of decors that transport you to ancient Egypt, New York, Madagascar, Hollywood, and beyond. In all there are 24 attractions in seven themed areas. The fairy-tale world of Shrek will fascinate the little ones, while you discover the incredible scenic route of the Transformers movie. Then embark on a dizzying descent, as a roller coaster plunges you into a magical and hyper-real 3D universe. The experience is breath-taking!

If the waiting time between two attractions is a bit too long, take a break in one of 30 restaurants or linger in one of the many shops selling often-surprising movie merchandise.

Universal Studios Singapore
8 Sentosa Gateway
Singapore

+65 6269 3411

www.rwsentosa.com/Homepage/Attractions/UniversalStudiosSingapore

content.title: Buddha Tooth Relic Temple: for a moment of meditation

introduction.small: In Chinatown, the majestic Buddha Tooth Relic Temple and Museum reveals a different yet essential side of Singapore.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Buddha Tooth Relic Temple: for a moment of meditation

paragraphs.text:
Inaugurated in 2007, this sacred place of worship stands majestically in the middle of the city. The serene atmosphere is conducive to meditation.

The chime of soft music, the smell of incense, and the purple and golden colours will transport your senses. The interior is extremely lavish. The floor is paved with gold, the walls and ceilings are adorned with paintings and sculptures, and thousands of statues decorate the rooms: Buddhas, dragons, flowers, and lanterns of breath-taking beauty. Lose yourself on the different floors and in the hanging gardens.

Spin the prayer wheel and get carried away into another world. The museum presents the history of Buddhism in an original way, and is filled with beautiful objects. If you wish to also attend a ceremony, do so in the evening, as these are the most striking moments of worship.

Buddha Tooth Relic Temple and Museum
288 South Bridge Road
Singapore

+65 6220 0220

www.btrts.org.sg/english-home

content.title: S.E.A. Aquarium: an aquatic dip in the seabeds of the world

introduction.small: One of the largest aquariums in the world, the S.E.A. Aquarium provides a true window on the secrets of the underwater world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: S.E.A. Aquarium: an aquatic dip in the seabeds of the world

paragraphs.text:
Divided into ten zones where 49 marine habitats are presented, the diversity of species swimming before your eyes is absolutely mind-blowing. The Asian seabed, the warm waters of the Persian Gulf, the Red Sea, and the great lakes of Africa this is a journey to the heart of marine life.

You begin your journey in the company of the kings of the deep, and stopover in the sea of sharks. Then let your imagination wander to the magical panorama of the Open Ocean, where huge manta rays and other sea giants orchestrate a perfectly synchronous ballet with sawfish and giant groupers. In the waters of the Bay of Bengal, try to find the archerfish, which stun their prey by shooting a jet of water up to 50 centimetres above the surface. Then navigate to the Andaman Sea, where marine leopards and other predators swim under your feet. More than a visual experience, the aquarium also has a ‘Discovery Touch Pool' where you can caress the starfish.

Then finish your tour in the waters of the Strait of Karimata, where exotic trevally and other eccentrically shaped and coloured fish swim about in a giant sunken ship.

S.E.A. Aquarium Sentosa
8 Sentosa Gateway
Sentosa Island
Singapore

+65 6577 8888

www.rwsentosa.com/Homepage/Attractions/SEAAquarium

content.title: The Curry Culture: the art of curry mastered to perfection

introduction.small: Taste the best curries in Singapore in a warm and friendly atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Curry Culture: the art of curry mastered to perfection

paragraphs.text:
Located in a quiet street adjacent to Orchard Road, The Curry Culture unveils its secret ingredient: passion! Masters of complexity in the mixture of spices, the chefs concoct a lunch or dinner prepared according to Indian tradition, and to perfection.

The service is warm and friendly, and the restaurant has a lovely terrace overlooking the colonial-era shops. Whether you're a carnivore or a vegetarian, you'll find your bliss. Besides the curries, the menu features tandoori, rice, and traditional breads.

For a most adventurous experience, try the marvellously fragrant vindaloo curry. Accompany your meal with delicious saffron rice and then cool off with a refreshing mango lassi.

The Curry Culture
31 Cuppage Road
Singapore

+65 6235 6133

www.thecurryculture.com.sg

Menu: from 40 SGD

content.title: The Hotel Vagabond: Parisian chic in Singapore

introduction.small: All in red, with photographs, golden sculptures, and trees with golden leaves that touch the ceilings. Here, art is at the fore.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Hotel Vagabond: Parisian chic in Singapore

paragraphs.text:
Designed by French architect Jacques Garcia, who redid the Royal Monceau in Paris and the Mamounia in Marrakech, the Vagabond Hotel has attractive features and a very strong personality and character. The fully restored 1920s Art Deco building is in the Kampong Glam neighbourhood, close to the Sultan Mosque and Arab Street. Every detail of the cosy decor, rich in colours and refined materials, has been carefully conceived. Reserve a table at the restaurant, serving Singapore specialities – like Malaysian quesadillas and wagyu burgers – or try one of the bars' artisanal creations. There is also an artist-in-residence studio for women artists from around the world. This is an exceptional boutique hotel, where guests are swept up in an inspiring universe of art the minute they walk through the door.

Hotel Vagabond
39 Syed Alwi Road
Singapore

+65 6291 6677

www.hotelvagabondsingapore.com

Rooms: from 240 SGD

content.title: Marina Bay Sands: an incomparable view overlooking the city

introduction.small: Just above the bay of Singapore stands this huge hotel complex, the new jewel of Singapore, built by the Israeli-Canadian architect Moshe Safdie.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Marina Bay Sands: an incomparable view overlooking the city

paragraphs.text:
The city's newest creation, this hotel complex, which consists of three 55-storey buildings connected by a giant terrace, has become one of the city's most resplendent jewels.

The rooms offer simple and elegant five-star luxury. A highlight is the 146-metre-long infinity pool. The dizzying spectacle unfolding around the hotel is breath-taking the view over the marina is one of the most beautiful in all of Singapore. There is almost no need to ever leave this giant complex, as it provides for all creature comforts.

Stroll through its shopping mall, place a bet or two in the casino, and visit the museum, all inside a surprising, lotus-shaped architectural structure, before relaxing in one of its many bars and restaurants.

Marina Bay Sands
10 Bayfront Avenue
Marina Bay
Singapore

+65 6688 8868

www.marinabaysands.com

Rooms: from 430 SGD

content.title: Food Tour Singapore: the many tastes of Singapore

introduction.small: A cultural as well as culinary tour that will stimulate your taste buds with the authentic flavours of the capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Food Tour Singapore: the many tastes of Singapore

paragraphs.text:
Why not contemplate the city from a new perspective? Singapore Food Tour invites you to a delightful culinary experience.

Accompanied by a local guide who knows all the secrets of the city, you'll visit Chinatown, where you'll discover specifically chosen places that are beloved by Singaporeans. Try the oyster cake bakkutteh; or a meat stew garnished with a complex mixture of herbs and spices; or the famous popiah, rolls of sweet vegetables in a thin pancake; orpisanggoreng, fried plantain banana slices.

You'll sample about ten local dishes in total, each with unique, quirky, and delicious flavours, many of which you probably would never have dared try on your own. Don't show up with a full stomach!

Food Tour Singapore
120 Maxwell Road
Singapore

+65 6223 4064

www.foodtoursingapore.com/#company

content.title: Makansutra Glutton's Bay: a delicious journey of simple, authentic cuisine

introduction.small: This open-air canteen reflects the uniqueness of Singaporean culture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Makansutra Glutton's Bay: a delicious journey of simple, authentic cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Open only in the evening, the Makansutra Glutton's Bay has ten different stands in an open canteen perched above the beautiful landscape of Marina Bay and the Fullerton Hotel.

Here you'll find authentic Southeast Asian cooking in a relaxed but lively atmosphere. The staple dishes of Singaporean cuisine are all here: beef, chicken, or lamb satay (meat skewers with a peanut sauce), crab chilli, char kwayteow (stir-fried flat rice noodles with vegetables and fried shrimp in soy sauce) sambalsotong (fried spicy squid, marinated in chilli sauce) oyster omelette, and carrot cake.

Have a refreshing Singaporean beer with your meal, and breathe in the unique aromas found in this enchanting atmosphere.

Makansutra Glutton's Bay
8 Raffles Ave #01-15
Singapore

+65 6336 7025

www.makansutra.com

Menu: from 30 SGD

content.title: Orchard Road: a shopping paradise

introduction.small: Emblematic avenue of the city, Orchard Road covers an incredible range of international and local brands, for a comprehensive shopping spree.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Orchard Road: a shopping paradise

paragraphs.text:
Bordered by tall trees, this two-kilometre commercial thoroughfare has many hotels and shopping centres. It offers a plethora of choices, including all the big names in international fashion, in an atmosphere of luxury and refinement.

Modern, dynamic, and clean, just like the city, Orchard Road is a nice play for a stroll you could fill a whole day here. There are modern sculptures at the entrance of buildings, and some of the shopping centres have interesting art galleries. Take a break for lunch in one of the many restaurants, or try the different food stalls in the shopping centres.

During the holidays, especially in December, Orchard Road is beautifully adorned with decorations and lights, creating a beautiful setting.

Orchard Road
Singapore

+65 6733 1700

www.orchardroad.org

content.title: Capella Singapore: a haven of peace for an exceptional stay

introduction.small: At the crossroads of the South China Sea and Singapore, here there's stunning scenery and personalised service, performed flawlessly.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Capella Singapore: a haven of peace for an exceptional stay

paragraphs.text:
Located on Sentosa Island, the Capella Singapore building formerly hosted the naval officers who came to celebrate with their loved ones while keeping an eye on the harbour entrance.

Upon arrival in the magnificent garden of tropical greenery, the curved structures and modern design of this charming colonial building take you for a journey into the past. The rooms overlook the tropical garden or the South China Sea. They are decorated to perfection, in a carefully studied marriage of the old and the modern. Rejuvenate in the ‘vitality' pool or the ice fountain, and then warm up in the steam bath with herbal preparations before relaxing in one of the private gardens.

Here reigns a perfect harmony between nature and Asian-infused luxury. It is a marvellous way to escape from the frenzy of the city.

Capella Singapore
1 The Knolls
Sentosa Island
Singapore

+65 6377 8888

www.capellahotels.com/singapore/

Rooms: from 500 SGD

content.title: Steer a course to the heart of the city's wonders

introduction.small: See the city from a completely different perspective and enjoy the cultural treasures along the Singapore River.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Steer a course to the heart of the city's wonders

paragraphs.text:
Climb aboard this charming electric boat designed according to tradition, and voyage through Singaporean history. Navigating the Singapore River provides a real understanding of the capital, which was built around the harbour, and its very dynamic evolution.

Enjoy the quiet of the trip, the quality of service, and an unparalleled perspective on the city. Be guided by your imagination and travel back to Singapore a century ago, when workers and sailors were busy loading and unloading trading ships at Boat Quay. In 1860, over three quarters of the world's merchant seamen passed through this place. On the water and its lively docks, modern Singapore is now unveiled before your eyes. Admire the details of the Helix Bridge, built in the form of DNA, before you immerse yourself in the magnificent Marina Bay. At night, the bridges and docks sparkle under the coloured lights.

For those seeking a more intimate approach, choose a Duffy boat, an option that offers a similar trip, but for small groups only. Ideal for a romantic evening or a business cocktail.

Singapore River Cruise
59 Boat Quay
Singapore

+65 6336 6111

www.rivercruise.com.sg/index.php
